greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Permutation of natural numbers: a(1) = 1; a(2n) = A087686(1+a(n)), a(2n+1) = A088359(a(n)), where A088359 and A087686 = numbers that occur only once (resp. more than once) in A004001.
comment: This sequence can be represented as a binary tree. Each left hand child is produced as A087686(1+n), and each right hand child as A088359(n), when their parent contains n:

The level k of the tree contains all numbers of binary width k, like many base-2 related permutations (A003188, A054429, etc). For a proof, see A267110, which gives the contents of each parent node (for node containing n).
A276442 shows the mirror-image of the same tree.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..8192
T. Kubo and R. Vakil, On Conway's recursive sequence, Discr. Math. 152 (1996), 225-252.
Index entries for sequences that are permutations of the natural numbers
formula: As a composition of other permutations:
a(2^n) = 2^n. [Follows from the properties (3) and (4) of A004001 given on page 227 of Kubo & Vakil paper.]
a(A000225(n)) = A006127(n), i.e., a((2^(n+1)) - 1) = 2^n + n. [Numbers at the right edge.]
xref: Cf. also permutations A266411, A266412 and arrays A265901, A265903.
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Jan 10 2016
